contextId.information: The writer compares the path of righteous people to the sunrise, meaning that they are safe because they have light to see where they are walking. AT: "righteous people walk along their path safely because the morning sun shines on it and grows brighter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: the path of righteous people is like the first light that grows brighter

contextId.information: The writer compares the way of wicked people to darkness, meaning that they are always in danger because they have no light to see where they are walking. AT: "Wicked people walk dangerously along their path because they have no light to be able to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The way of the wicked is like darkness

contextId.information: Just as storm comes and sweeps everything away so wicked people will disappear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The wicked are like the storm

contextId.information: A beautiful woman without discretion is compared to a useless and unsuitable golden ring in a pig's nose. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Like a gold ring ... without discretion

contextId.information: The writer compares the lifestyle of the sluggard with trying to walk through a hedge of thorns. Both cause the person to suffer pain. AT: "The life of the sluggard is like a person trying to walk through a hedge of thorns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The path of the sluggard is like a place with a hedge of thorns

contextId.information: This speaks of a person's bribe working by comparing it to a magical stone or amulet. AT: "A bribe works like a magical stone for the one who gives it" or "A bribe works like magic for the one who is giving the bribe" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: A bribe is like a magic stone to the one who gives it

contextId.information: Here the lion's roaring refers to attacking. The wrath of a king is compared to the unpredictable and dangerous attack of a young lion. AT: "The wrath of the king is as dangerous as the attack of a young lion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The wrath of the king is like the roaring of a young lion

contextId.information: This compares how people fear a king's wrath to how they fear a young roaring lion. AT: "The king's wrath makes people as afraid as if they were facing a young lion roaring at them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The fear of a king is like the fear of a young lion that is roaring

contextId.information: This speaks of how difficult it is to understand the reasons for a person's actions by comparing it to the difficulty of reaching the water in a deep well. AT: "It is as difficult to understand the purpose in the human heart as it is to reach the water in a deep well" or "The purpose of in the human heart is very difficult to understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The purpose in a human heart is like deep water

contextId.information: Normally snow does not fall during the summer and rain does not fall during  the harvest. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Just as it would be very strange to have snow in summer or rain during the harvest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Like snow in summer or rain in harvest

contextId.information: The phrases can be reordered. AT: "A proverb in the mouth of fools is like the legs of a paralytic which hang down" or " A proverb in the mouth of fools is as useless as the legs of a paralytic which hang down" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Like the legs ... is a proverb in the mouth of fools

contextId.information: How the two are alike can be stated clearly. AT: "A proverb in the mouth of fools is as dangerous as a thorn that goes into the hand of a drunkard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Like a thorn ... is a proverb in the mouth of fools

contextId.information: This speaks of gossip being desirable to listen to as if it were delicious food to eat. AT: "The words of a gossip are desirable to listen to" or (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The words of a gossip are like delicious morsels
